pages.text: Conulariids are a group of Paleozoic and Triassic cnidarians that are commonly found all over the world. They possess a conical shell which would have surrounded their soft bodies. These organisms were also likely sessile feeders.

They are generally extremely small, measuring up to only a few centimeters in the length of their shell. Conulariids, like conodonts and ammonites, are also commonly used as index fossils due to their fossils being really common.
They are generally believed to have used their tentacles to ensnare prey, and as they grew older, conulariids may have become recumbent, or tipped over.
